<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Looking at class size dataset, we see the school Roberto Clemente has repeats in Grade and Program Type. Grades makes sense, as we explained earlier, and so does Program_type, as it seems to indicate, special education, general education etc. We know that we have to restrict each field to a single value, as ultimately the program types and grade types create duplicate rows. This will interfere with total class_size however; we fix that by computing class_size averages for each school and using that average for our overall correlations (this assumes that each class within each school is about the same, but that seems a fair assumption)</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#we pick gen_ed as program tpye, and 09-12 as grade type category. We then group by DBN, and aggregate the mean class</span>
<span class="c1">#sizes, aka find the average class size of each school and reset the value to that average</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Class_size"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"GRADE "</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"09-12"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"PROGRAM TYPE"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"GEN ED"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">inplace</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Class_size"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we move onto condensing the demographics dataset. This dataset seems ok besides one issue with multiple years for the same school, resulting in a similar multiple rows problem. We fix this by picking the most recent school years available for each set (2011 or 2012), and this solves the multiple rows issue.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">demographics</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Demographics"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">demographics</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">demographics</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">demographics</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"schoolyear"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">20112012</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Demographics"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">demographics</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We then move onto the math_test_results set. Same issue of multiple rows as data is segmented by both grade and by year. We select a single grade from each single year, which in this case we choose to be grade 8 and 2011.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [33]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"Year"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="mi">2011</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"Grade"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'8'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we do the same thing with the graduation dataset. In this case we fix the issue by just picking one cohort year, 2006</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [34]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"Cohort"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"2006"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"Demographic"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s2">"Total Cohort"</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Computing-Variables-and-Correlations">Computing Variables and Correlations<a class="anchor-link" href="#Computing-Variables-and-Correlations">¶</a></h1><p>Having cleansed the data to a reasonable degree to this point ,mainly by removing extraneous variables, and condensing multiple rows of data for single schoools, we can now proceed to compute and combine certain variables that will make it easier to compute actual correleations. The first one we focus on is the total SAT score. In the data, the scores 
are listed as "strings" and divided by subject. We first convert these strings to integers, and then add them to create a new total average score variable. We print the head of the data later on to check if this variable is in the dataset and if its total value makes sense.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [35]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">cols</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SAT Math Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'SAT Writing Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">c</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"SAT_Results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"SAT_Results"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_objects</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">convert_numeric</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SAT_Results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SAT_Results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SAT_Results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'SAT_Results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="c1">#convert_objects has been deprecated, but infer_objects() creates an issue. </span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stderr output_text">
<pre>/Users/nikhilprasad/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:3: FutureWarning: convert_objects is deprecated.  To re-infer data dtypes for object columns, use Series.infer_objects()
For all other conversions use the data-type specific converters pd.to_datetime, pd.to_timedelta and pd.to_numeric.
  This is separate from the ipykernel package so we can avoid doing imports until
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#for k,v in data.items():</span>
    <span class="c1">#print(k)</span>
    <span class="c1">#print(v.head())</span>
    <span class="c1">#print('\n')</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Combining-Data">Combining Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Combining-Data">¶</a></h1><p>We now combine the data using the DBN column as a unique identifier. The end result will be a dataset with tons of columns from all the original data sets. If there are potential data sets with missing columns (in this case there are not) We could resolve this by merging datasets with missing rows using outer join, which will basically give us a "union" of all the datasets, with null values in the datasets that don't have those specific columns. In the data used in the blog post, there was one missing column in AP_results. The data that I took from NYC open data does not have that missing value.</p>
<p>In the code below, we loop through all the items (datasets) in the data dictionary we created at the beginning. If the item column value is in one of the 3 listed datasets (sat_results, ap, graduation), we do an outer join (union) if it is not, then we merge into the full dataset object.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [49]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">flat_data_names</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">k</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">v</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">items</span><span class="p">()]</span>
<span class="n">flat_data</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">k</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">flat_data_names</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">full</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">flat_data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">f</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">enumerate</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">flat_data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">:]):</span>
    <span class="n">name</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">flat_data_names</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">name</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">-</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">unique</span><span class="p">()))</span>
    <span class="n">join_type</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"inner"</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">name</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"SAT_results"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"AP_Results"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"Graduation_Outcomes"</span><span class="p">]:</span>
        <span class="n">join_type</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"outer"</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">name</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"Math_test_results"</span><span class="p">]:</span>
        <span class="n">full</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">f</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">join_type</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">

survey

</pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[49]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>(320, 163)</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We now have the shape of our full dataset in that dataframe above. The last things we want to do before computing correlations with different variables are to turn them from strings in the data into numbers. AP_Results is something that we defintiely want to correlate with SAT_results, but the data in the AP dataset is in strings. The code below converts that into numbers and then fils in missing values (NaN) with 0. Then in the following step, we fill in any of the missing values with their mean. This is just taking the mean data per column and filling the zero values with that.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [51]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">cols</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'AP Test Takers '</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Total Exams Taken'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Number of Exams with scores 3 4 or 5'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">col</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">col</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">col</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">convert_objects</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">convert_numeric</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stderr output_text">
<pre>/Users/nikhilprasad/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:4: FutureWarning: convert_objects is deprecated.  To re-infer data dtypes for object columns, use Series.infer_objects()
For all other conversions use the data-type specific converters pd.to_datetime, pd.to_timedelta and pd.to_numeric.
  after removing the cwd from sys.path.
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [55]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Data-Analysis">Data Analysis<a class="anchor-link" href="#Data-Analysis">¶</a></h1><p>Below, we'll use the corr function to calculate correlations against SAT_score with all the variables within the full dataframe. The results are listed below. From there we will explore certain aspects of this data based on the correlations we find. We'll start by looking at a plot of sat_scores against total enrollment.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [58]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[58]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We see some usual suspects at the top of the list for correlations in that we can intuitively expect high positive correlation between AP test takers, number of total exams taken, or people who have scored passing grades (3,4,5) on AP tests. We can explore those later, but one of the ones that jumps out as having a decent positive correlation but not being easily intuitive is total enrollment. One of the ways to glean more from this data is to graph it, as I have done below.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [57]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline 
<span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'total_enrollment'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[57]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10eaf9898></pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
" />
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The graph shows that there is a big cluster of schools within the bottom left corner of the graph, i.e. a bunch of low 
enrollment schools (1000 students or less) and low SAT scores. There doesn't seem to be much correlation between positive (high enrollment) and high SAT scores, so clearly this is actually not a good correlation that we can use to hypothesize some sort of positive relationship between enrollment and SAT score, i.e. higher enrollment does not lead to higher SAT_scores. That cluster is just influencing the data.This implies that there is some other variable at work that is being "flattened" or misrepresented by total enrollment and skewing towards a positive correlation with SAT_score. We can further explore this by looking through our dataframe at the schools that are in that low cluster.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [61]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[(</span><span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"total_enrollment"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">1100</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sat_score"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">1100</span><span class="p">)][</span><span class="s2">"School Name"</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[61]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Looking through the data, we see some of these schools are international. This means that there are potentially a lot of students that are learning english as a second language. That could be one possible "hidden variable" that is causing. One can also look up some of the schools and see that schools like "Community School for Social Justice" among others are potentially in low income neighborhoods, perhaps indicating that there are less resources. This can be explored further based on the specific angle of research that needed to be done. We don't have much direct income data, but we can further test the first hypothesis (that low SAT scores are not correlated with enrollment, rather with English as a second language) by testing against the ell_percent variable, which is the percentage of students in each school that are learning english as a second language. I do this below by creating a scatter plot.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [65]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'ell_percent'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[65]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10eaa7978></pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
" />
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This shows a soft confirmation of that hypothesis, as there is a small bunch of low SAT scores correlated with high ell_percent. We could further explore this by finding district data, and mapping it againt the ell_percent, depending on if that was the goal of the project or not. For right now, I will move onto exploring another relationship, which a correlation between sat_scores against the survey variables, to try to glean if there is a relationship between parents who responded to the school surveys and sat scores.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [63]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="s2">"sat_score"</span><span class="p">][[</span><span class="s2">"rr_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_tot_11"</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[63]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10eacd080></pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
" />
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The two factors with the highest correlations are N_p and N_s, which are variables in the survey that correspond to the number of parents and students that responded to the survey. We can make several "guesses" as to why this might be, perhaps a higher parent and student response could indicate more attention towards school, which would imply more of a concern of parents to make sure their kids do well in school and in SAT scores. We could also make inferences about income. All of this however would require further analysis and data. One possible variable I would explore would be amount of money spent by parents on SAT tutoring and see if it is highly correlated with survey response. This data however is very hard to find in public record. Another one I would explore is average district income. I would expect that higher income parents with more stability would be able to spend more time on their students. We could also see how these variables correlate against total enrollment, (they correlate strongly) and make the previous connection to high ell_percent and low SAT_scores. We could also look at the third variable in this list that highly correlates, which is saf_tot_11. This variable corresponds to how safe students, teachers, and parents percieve the school to be. My intuition is that this is all getting at a "hidden variable" of district and neighborhood income, as we have seen countless other studies done in this domain that indicate the SAT scores and education in general becomes a factor of socioeconomic situations (which I can see correlating with safety) , and we have also seen many low income familes, particularly hispanic households (as we saw with the high race correlation) be affected by this. This would depend on the aims of a specific project.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [64]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="s2">"sat_score"</span><span class="p">][[</span><span class="s2">"white_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"asian_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"black_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"hispanic_per"</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[64]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10eac3208></pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
" />
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now I look at correlations between race and sat_scores. We further see more tangential evidence of income as a hidden variable, as schools that have higher percentages of white and asian students are higher correlated positively with sat_scores, while schools with higher percentage of black and hispanic students are negatively correlated with SAT scores. One can look at the ell_percentage as a possible variable also, as it makes sense that students who have trouble speaking english would have trouble with their SAT scores. However, I stll think the greater factor is income disparity, and if I was further extending this project, I would map districts by income and overlay it against this data. However right now I will continue to do more broad analysis, and move onto gender data and testing it against SAT_scores.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [66]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="s2">"sat_score"</span><span class="p">][[</span><span class="s2">"male_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"female_per"</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[66]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x10ea9c6a0></pre>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_area">
<div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
" />
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We see a strong positive correlation with schools with higher female percentage students than male percentage students. There could be many reasons for this. We'll once again plot the school data against scores to see what this shows us visually.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [67]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The scatter plot shows us some significant outliers with schools of more than 50 percent female enrollment and high sat scores in the middle top right of the graph. It is not a cluster of data, but that sort of grouping warrants further analysis. So we then look at the names of the schools that fit into that subset of the data. A large portion of these schools are performing arts schools. Some of the others are elite schools in high income districts. There doesn't seem to be a very strong case here, but we can say that these elite performance arts schools have more females and that they tend to focus more on making sure their students do well on standardized exams. There are other hypotheses we can test but they would require a far greater understanding of the domain space (educational gender differences) and more granular data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The last thing I'll do is the obvious intuition one. The high correlation between more students taking and doing well on AP exams and high SAT scores.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [74]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"ap_avg"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"AP Test Takers "</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">full</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"total_enrollment"</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">full</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'ap_avg'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area">

<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">

" />
</div>

</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This shows extremely strong correlation between the two. We can explore the grouping of schools at the top right, which have very high SAT scores and very high proportions of students taking AP exams.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</pre></div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This data shows some of the best schools in the city, including names like Stuyvesant, which are considered some of the most prestigous high schools in the country, and ones that most definitely have very high income students with parents willing to pay tuition, and also very high academic standards, which could reflect itself in entry test scores, and the qualifications of their teachers. This is another angle that could be further explored.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This project was more so for me to get a feel for data analysis of a random dataset, just to see what possible angles one could take if potentially exploring doing a project trying to "prove" a specific fact e.g. (high income neighborhoods do better on sat and standardized tests) or trying to build a model to accomplish something else.</p>
</div>
